div.l: For whiche this Myller͗e stale bothe mele and corne
An hundred tyme more than he did bi forne
For ther biforne he stale but curteysly
But nowe he was a thef to outragyously
For the whiche / the warden chidde and maad fare
But therof the miller set nat a tare
He craked bost and swoor it was nat so
Than were ther yong poure scolerys two
That dwelton̄ in the halle / of which y seye
Testyf they were and lusty / for to pley
And only for her myrthe and her revelrye
Vppon ther wardeyn / ful besily they crye
To yeve hem leve / but a litel stoıı̄unde
To gon to mille / and seen her corne I grounde
And hardily / thei durst leyn̄ her necke
The miller shulde nat stele hem half a pecke
Of corne ne bi sleyht / ne bi force hem bereve
And at the last / the warden yaf hem leve
Iohn hyht that on / aleyn̄ hycht that othir
Of o toıı̄un wer thei born̄ / that hyht strothir
Fer in the north / I can nat telle where
This Aleyn̄ maketh redy al this ger͗e
And on an hors / he cast the sek a non
Forth goth Aleyn the Clerk and Iohn
Wyth swerde and bokeler bi his side
Iohn knew the way wel him nedid no guyde
And at the mylle the sak doıı̄un he layth
Aleyn̄ spake first al heil symond in fayth
How faris thi faire douhtir / and thi wyf
Wel come Aleyn̄ ꝙquod symkyn be my lyf
And Iohn Also / oouh what do ye now here
By god ꝙquod Iohn / nede hath no pere
Hym bihovis serve hin self that hath no swayn
